segments.text: You can't get the pictures on the tape.
This is an interview with Geraldine Ann Johnson, maiden name Hart, by Tracy L. Swope on 4 December in Temple concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection and the University Archives.
Is this all right with you?
Yes, this is all right with me.
My first question is, can you please give us some background on your life, and why did you join the service?
I'm the eldest of eight children of a Marine Corps officer for 29 years, and I grew up at places like El Toro and Cherry Point, and I graduated from high school in 1961.
My father was the

kind of person that people were in those days and as far as he was concerned as an Irish Catholic I had three possible futures as the eldest of eight children and a daughter I could go into the convent I could become a teacher or I could become a nurse at the time I had some degree of flair for languages and I had studied two languages in high school and was very taken with the glamour and romance of the Foreign Service
and had been accepted to the Georgetown School of Foreign Affairs and, of course, had no money to go.
And nobody was giving scholarship money to 16-year-old girls in those days.
I had not turned 17 when I graduated.
So a friend of mine who had always wanted to be a nurse all her life, her dad was a Navy captain, was going to go to Georgetown University to a nursing school.
And she had the catalog.
And lo and behold, it said that if you were a registered nurse and worked in our hospital, you got six free semester hours a semester.
Well, I allowed it to happen.
As young as I was, I could piss away three years in a nursing school somewhere and become an RN and then go to Georgetown and work my way through the School of Foreign Affairs.
So that was my plan.
And I went off to Maryview Hospital in Portsmouth, Virginia, which ran a diploma school of nursing, to embark on this plan.
It was during that period of time, from 62 through 65, that all the events that kicked Vietnam loose as a war for our country transpired.

I vividly remember being a student nursing, coming back to the dormitory on the break, and the television was on, and President Johnson was talking about the Tonkin Bay, or Gulf incident, and when they had fired on our ships.
Well, about midway through my junior year,
I got interested in the scholarship plans.
And at that point in time, the Navy Nurse Corps was only taking students from college programs.
And the Army and the Air Force were taking students from both college and diploma programs.
And so I had focused in on the Air Force and the Army.
And to be quite honest, the Army recruiter was doing his job.
He was personable.
He was interested.
He followed up on us.

and he just pursued us hotly there were about six of us in my class that he was convinced would be wonderful nurse corps officers as a matter of fact he succeeded in recruiting four of us and we signed up for the army student nurse program which in those days they swore you in as a pfc in the women's army reserve and you were on active duty as a student nurse you made 99.37 a month now until that time my father had dutifully sent me a 25 check every month as my allowance
and I bought everything I needed with $25 a month that wasn't provided by my school, which was room, board, uniforms, books, pretty much everything provided.
But I mean, soap powder, makeup, all that stuff, I was on a $25 a month allowance, and I thought I had got rich.
$99.37 a month was just, you know, your major increase in status.
And so my senior year was quite comfy.
I just did anything I felt like doing.
I guess I had lived on a beer budget so long that I didn't really have much taste for champagne, and I just had a marvelous time.
And indeed, when I graduated, I was committed to join the Army Nurse Corps for two years.
In fact, I was in the Army.
If I didn't pass state boards, I was going to get to be an enlisted medic.
And of course, in those days, people passed state boards.
There wasn't any if to it.
The schools taught to the boys.
But anyway, I was put out on leave to entertain myself until my state board results came back.
And I went to work at George Washington University Hospital.
Dad had three consecutive tours that they lived in the same house for.
He was at the Navy Annex, and then he was at Henderson.
No, then he was at the Chief of Naval Operations Office, and then he was at Henderson Hall.

and so they were three PCS tours but they lived in the same house six blocks from Fort Myer North Gate in Arlington, Virginia during that whole period of time that I was going through nurses training and for many years thereafter it was a nine-year stint there.
Consequently my four youngest sisters and brothers grew up in that house and have a totally different
idea of what life is like than the four older of us who grew up moving around on air bases.

Anyway, my state boards came through and in sometime in the middle of August in 65 I reported to Fort Sam Houston, Texas where I went through basic at the medical field service school and for a little girl who was

19 who had just been in a convent school of nursing for three years it was really quite quite an experience not exactly academically challenging and I had just never seen so much steak beer and cute guys in my life and I had a wonderful time and it's a good thing it didn't last longer than nine weeks because I don't think my metabolism could have kept up and
At that point in time it was, you know, full bore.
They ran the school where they had so many companies of doctors and a company of medical service corps officers and two companies of nurses and, you know, that kind of thing.
We were all there for nine weeks at the same time and then every nine weeks they just turned it over and cleared the barracks out and ran in another bunch.
And everybody had orders to stay inside places.
And everybody knew that within a year, they were probably going to start rotating overseas one place or another.
At the time, I had put on my dream sheet that I wanted to go to Nancy, France, which was the last US Army hospital in France.
But it was during my senior year, after I turned in my dream sheet, that France quit NATO and they closed that hospital.
So I wasn't going to France.
But most of my friends were angling to go to Europe one way or another.
I got stamped with 50 of my classmates to Walter Reed in Washington, D.C., right back where I came from.
Never been so damn disgusted in my life.
And what had happened is that they had mobilized one of the, I forget what they called them in those days, Strack Unit hospitals, you know what they called them?
And it was a warehouse

ghost hospital nothing but supplies and a couple of sergeants to count them and they had stripped all the big hospitals in the states of active duty personnel to staff this thing and had shipped it over to Vietnam and they shipped 50 of us into Walter Reed all on the same reporting day to replace these people and we were put on duty that day and Walter Reed at that point in time had been running without these people for about two weeks
Everybody was on six-day weeks, and they were on 12-hour days.
And I worked on 12-hour days and six-day weeks for the three months that I was at good old Walter Reed.
We suddenly realized that the 50 of us they had sent there were all nurses, and three of the nurses were guys.
And we were now back where everybody was married, majors, and colonels.
And it was really very unsociable, and it was very expensive.
And lieutenants in Washington, DC just

it's not a survival mode and I was bleeding on my father's shoulder about how I certainly did not join the army to putter my time away at Walter Reed for heaven's sakes it was just awful and he said well honey what you need to do is you need to put on your greens make an appointment make an appointment that's important to see the chief nurse march in report to her desk and request orders for Vietnam
I said, okay, so I went back and I called the nice sergeant who was her desk personage and told him that I wanted an appointment with Colonel Barrett and I still remember her name.

And he gave me one at 8 o'clock on Monday morning the following Monday and I put my greens on and marched smartly into her office and snapped two in front of her desk and Lieutenant Hart reporting, ma'am, and I would like to request reassignment to Vietnam.

and she looked at me and she said you're not ready to go to Vietnam lieutenant because you can't even get your uniform on right you don't have your bars on yes ma'am I'll fix that so I went back and I called my dad in tears and he said honey yeah you live and learn she said call back and make an appointment for next Monday at eight o'clock I had five consecutive Monday morning eight o'clock appointments with Colonel Barrett
And each time it got to be a game, okay, Lieutenant, you've been here.
Thank you, ma'am.
Dismissed.
Out the other face, and out I go.
Every morning.
The ward I was on was Ward 36, and it was 40 beds, and six of them up front were what are now ICU beds.
They were mainly the close to the nurse's station beds in those days.
And all but five of the patients on that ward, and it was full all the time.
had come from the Yodrang Valley Battle, and they were all from the 1st Air Cav.
And average age, discounting the other five patients, was probably all of 23 or 24.
And they all, it was a general surgery and plastic surgery floor.
So I had a lot of the guys with avulsion wounds who were awaiting granulation healing so that they could go in for complex plastic surgery techniques.
And had one kid, Sergeant Starr, who had been shot in the canteen.
And if you think about physics and metal canteens, what happens when you have a fluid under pressure?
That canteen exploded like a grenade and blew half his hip off.
Fortunately, it didn't involve any major arteries, major veins, major nerves, and it actually left most of the bone intact.
It just blew away all the flesh.
And so he had this big, great, massive mess that was healing him.
And I vividly remember that they decided he was
He was good enough to go home for Christmas on the 24th of December, and he came running into the ward panicky.
He had gotten his issue of clothes from the quartermaster, and the pants were unhemmed, and his bus left in an hour and a half.
And I sat down and hemmed his pants.
I mean, what else can you do?
It's hard to tell young student nurses nowadays that you could hem somebody's pants and not feel in the least bit subservient.

in today this does not not outrage my women's lib blood at all because that ward was a buddy ship Colonel Barrett probably had been harassed by somebody but for some reason she sent out a big memo to all the wards that the televisions were by regulation to be off at 10 p.m. and we were to enforce that well my guys laid in bed all day most of them were in pretty good condition health-wise

except their wounds permitted them or prevented them from being just bored to death and it was a big great hall with 20 beds down one side and 20 beds down the other and you know they had the two TVs one at one end of the ward one at the other and you know it was about all they had and the late movies were really pretty entertaining so I marched out I was the night nurse marched out and said

gentlemen I make rounds once an hour when I make rounds I'm very noisy so you know I'm coming when I'm making rounds I'm enforcing the prohibition about the televisions is that clear yes ma'am yes ma'am yes ma'am so you know 11 o'clock I'd slam the door in the medicine cupboard and clutter around and knock my flashlight on something and hear as the TVs went off everybody's just breathing quietly go back in you hear the TVs come right back on you know I never saw

television being on and they took good care of me and I took good care of them one day they were it didn't take long they knew I was the Marine Colonel's daughter and they also knew that I had been naive enough to apply for airborne training while I was in basic and I got the news broken to me that the army wasn't really an equal opportunity employer and that I couldn't go to airborne school and
So they allowed us how they were going to teach me themselves.

So I crawled up on his chair, and they were going to teach me how to do a parachute landing, and about eight or nine of them in their beds coaching me about how I'm supposed to fall off his chair properly.
And this little bald man in a white lab coat kind of came shambling by, and he didn't really say anything, but he looked pretty benign, and he kept trying on going, and

You know, I figured if he wanted something, he'd have stopped me, and it was the next day when I saw the picture in front of the dining hall that said he was the commander of Walter Reed Army Medical Center, General Mallory, Malloy, Mallory, something like that.
Anyway, we were buddies, and it worked out pretty well.
Anyway, after my visits, Colonel Barrett had known Sergeant General Heaton when he was...
She was a lieutenant nurse and he was a captain doctor, I think.
And she managed to get me shipped out ahead of regulations.
And I got my orders to report at Travis Air Force Base in California on the, I want to say it was the 4th of January.
Anyway, I took a week's leave and...
bummed hops out there.
It took me about three days to get there.
About a fairly zigzag route, but it didn't cost much.
And I had a wonderful time.
I was a hop bummer.
I really enjoyed that.
Just went anywhere I wanted to as long as there was an airplane with a seat going there.
And stayed in the Marine Memorial Hotel on Sutter Street that my father reckoned I'd be safe in.
And spent two or three days just shopping and sleeping late and puttering around and
Then met three of my friends from Basic who also had managed to get out of the places they'd been sent to, wonderful places like Fort Polk, Louisiana.
Really tells you something when youngsters like us would rather go to war than be stuck in some of these holes.
Anyway, one fun thing that happened that you may appreciate is that while I was dragging my duffel bag through the main hall of the big MAC terminal at Travis,
This little airman, first class, comes running out, now I'm a Butterbark lieutenant here, and asked me if he can help me with my bag.
And I smiled and said, no, I'm doing fine.
Rusty, what are you doing here?
It was one of our football heroes from when I was in high school, another Marine colonel's kid.
And he was very impressed with the fact that I was an officer.
So at any rate, got on the plane and 26 hours later got off of it.
This has got to be the longest plane ride I've ever experienced.
Do you feel the Army prepared you to go to Vietnam?
Did you receive any training?
Oh yeah, yeah.
In basic, we had a class advisor who we thought of as being as old as Noah's wife, and her name was Major Betts.
and I have found a picture of Major Betts around here somewhere.
Anyway, here she is.
Major Betts kept throwing in salty reminders.
She taught all of the etiquette and courtesy and how to wear your brass and how are things organized and arranged and

why is AR 670-4 important to you because it's the AR that covers absolutely everything that has to do with running hospitals and you know she kept throwing in salty references to what you should and should not do in combat she had been a youngster in Korea and had pretty well taken it on as her mission to get us sort of used to the idea that we were going to do this thing and I do run into her later in the story now
Yeah, did they prepare us completely?
I don't think anybody could have.
Most of those people, their career experiences weren't necessarily going to duplicate what we were dealing with.
They dealt with a fluid front, but we dealt with no front at all.
And it made all sorts of things, like can you go buy something in the village, different.
But in terms of an expectation of what to take with you and what was life going to be like,
It was reasonably well done, if you listened.
I had friends who didn't.
Where did you end up?
You relate to us your experience of actually landing in Vietnam and going to your unit.
Well, that big plane landed, and I had been very uncomfortably asleep with my head on the shoulder of another nurse, a guy who'd been in my basic class, who ended up on the same flight.
It turned out he was going to the same hospital, so we kind of linked up.
He's a

older guy who was married and had a couple kids and I had a bad crick in my neck from trying to sleep like this because we were packed in I'm sure four abreast in those airplanes but it must have been three but anyway it felt like four anyway uh Dave and I stumbled off the thing and you know went over they were running it pretty much like any other get off a big airplane operation went over and got our luggage and the next thing we know this wiry little dried up colonel nurse and an enlisted driver are standing there going
you know, are you lieutenants Hart and Ely?
And we said, yes, indeed.
And she said, I'm Colonel Coffey, and I've come to take you out to the third search.
And we're going to go by the third field and pick up a couple of things on our way.
So we went over.
The third field hospital was maybe all of six blocks away from Thompson Air Base.
And so we drove over there in this cracker box ambulance and went in.
And somebody gave us a glass of soda, which I was a little amused, not amused, but bemused at the time because it didn't have any ice in it.
It was cold.
It didn't have any ice in it.
I thought, hmm, strange.
We didn't have potable ice is what it was.
It was ice with soda caps in it that were supposed to tell you not to put it in anything because you couldn't drink it.
You could use it to chill down bottles and cans.
That's what I learned later.
And ever since then, I've been an ice-a-holic.
I fill a glass completely up with ice before I put beverage in it after 18 months with no ice.

But anyway, whatever business she had to do, she did, and we rode on out the 30 kilometers or so to the 173rd Space Camp, which was where our hospital was, at Bien Hoa, right off the air base, and chortled in there.

And she was wringing her hands when she was assigning us our bunks and telling us that the artillery across the street was going to start up their H&Is about 8 p.m., and she really was sorry because it was hard for anybody to sleep.
And I rolled into my bunk, and the next thing I knew, it was noon the next day.
I slept through the whole thing.
That's when I decided I probably, if they thought that was bad stuff and hard to sleep through, that I was probably going to do okay here.
What year was this?
This was in 1966.
January, by that time, 6th, I think.
Something like that.
Because you had to cross the date line in the wrong direction to get out there.
Anyway, I got assigned to the post-op ward.
The way the hospital was organized, it had pre-op, which was our ER shock trauma type thing, OR, post-op, and holding.
And to get on holding, you had to be ambulatory and have no IVs.
Post-op was everybody else.
OR, of course, was OR.
And pre-op, at that point in time, was an all-male operation, and only male nurses worked in pre-op.
And pre-op did everything.
They did the
immunizations, and they did blood banking.
They drew blood when they needed fresh blood.
And, of course, when the choppers landed, they stripped guys and started IVs and, you know, worked with getting them ready for surgery and that kind of thing.
And it was amazing.
In some ways, it was very similar to standard hospital nursing.
In other ways, it was very different.
The charts only had three kinds of forms on them.
I thought that was wonderful.
It had doctor's orders, and it had nurse's notes, and it had a sheet of stable lab slips, too.
That's all.
And if it, you know, that's all there was.
I think there was some merit to that.
We really ought to take a look at going back to that system.
That kind of thing was real simple.
We did some real complex surgery.
We had the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research
which I will hereafter refer to as rare, hemorrhagic shock research team with us.
It was two doctors, both of them were PhD bioengineers as well as BMDs, and a nurse, a male nurse, and a couple of fancy lab tech medic type guys.
And patients who we had been taught in basic were to be treated as expectant casualties, give them morphine and bring in the chaplain type things.
Those guys worked on and not,
not infrequently actually packed on aircraft and sent them back home.
And it became the norm in Vietnam surgery that we didn't really have expectant categories.
I mean, unless a guy was severed into bitsy pieces, if you still had a heart rate and respiration that could be supported, then we worked on them.
We didn't park people in the corner, which they had to do in Korea and Vietnam.
I mean, Korea in World War II, a lot.
We did some really kind of heroic stuff.
They brought in big, great fixed-wing aircraft from Clark Air Force Base and flew burn casualties in one shot with mid-air refueling all the way to Brook Army Medical Center in Texas from a war zone.
Of course, we never heard whether these guys lived or not, but we always assumed that no one would go to such heroic expense and trouble if there wasn't some chance.
When I got there, the unit was abuzz with the latest scandal, which was that one of the operating room nurses was a native of St. Louis.
And she had been very upset because the operating room did not have a defibrillator.
In fact, the hospital didn't have the defibrillator.
And they had had a guy die on a table that she really felt that they could have defibbed him.
He had come back and made it.
But I remember everybody we were working on was young, healthy men.
I mean, there was absolutely no excuse to throw in the towel.

So she, railing at the CO, who's just one of the surgeons, you know, why don't we have a defibrillator, was told it was not T-O-N-E for a MASH hospital because we were supposed to be a meatball surgery on the front lines kind of outfit.
She snorted off to her quarters and sat down and wrote a letter to the CEO of Anheuser-Busch and told him all about how she was a...
a Budweiser girl from St. Louis who was stuck out there in the middle of the war zone with no defibrillator and people were dying, good beer drinking people were dying of this.

And what had happened was the CEO of Anheuser-Busch picked up the phone, ordered the fanciest defibrillator available and put it on a civilian cargo aircraft to the embassy in Saigon with instructions that it be delivered to the third surgical hospital.
and then turned around and called his congressman.
So there was a full bore congressional investigation about why we didn't have defibrillators.
At the same time, we had the only defibrillator in the country at the time.
If I say kingdom, it's because we spent two years in Saudi Arabia, too.
And anyway, sure, her name was Mudd.
We had more little inspection tours and stuff coming around, and I was brand new and couldn't quite figure out why all these fancy, brassy people.
At least, having grown up with the military, I knew they were fancy.
A lot of my peers didn't even know that.
They thought that was how things always happened.
But anyway, we just did our thing.
That day when I woke up at noon, they told me that I'd be

on day shift on the ward the following day and that I better hurry up and get dressed because there was a party and off we lared up to a party and partied until the wee hours and then went to work in the morning and from then on out it was six day weeks and usually twelve hour days although we went through some slow periods when we backed off to eight hour shifts but that was the norm.
How did you cope with the men on the ward, the rangers?
I just did what I was supposed to.
We have our own little ritual that we do in medicine and nursing and how they got that way.
A guy can be crushed because a truck falls on him.
It doesn't matter whether it's a cement truck out at a construction site or whether it's a military truck in some motor pool.
What we deal with is the crushed chest.
And so we're obsessed with all our little gadgets and medicines and ventilators and IVs and how much of this has he had and how much did he put out in eight hours and all that kind of thing.
And that's what we did.
And I don't remember people making a lot of comments about how we got in the mess.
Of course, it was early on yet.
Did you grow attached to any of your patients?
Oh, grossly so.
Because it was this buddy ship thing going on.
And I guess maybe the verb attached makes me nervous.
Did I ever entertain romantic thoughts about them?
No.
I had a pretty rousing date life going as it was with people who were fit and hale and up and around.
And the patients went through fast.
We were a surgical hospital.
We evacuated as soon as we stabilized.
So it was very seldom that anybody stayed with us more than two days.
The ones who stayed with us more than two days were the ones who weren't stable enough to evacuate.
So they were, you know, not exactly your romantic dreams.
But oddly enough, we would get these guys who stayed who were unstable.
Everybody got obsessed with them.
And it got to where you couldn't have a conversation on anything else.
I had one, Sergeant Pennington, who changed my life.
because I got mad.
I had had a week and a half of Sergeant Pennington.
It had finally rolled around.
It was my day off.
I didn't have any place to go.
I didn't really have anything to do.
There was a big operation going on.
All the guys were in the field.
And, you know, I slept in, and I went to lunch, and everybody was talking about Sergeant Pennington's latest.
He was a triple amputee, multiple shrapnel, you know, 200-some debris to shrapnel wounds, you know, four chest tubes, and he was a mess.
And to be honest, I would be surprised if he lived.
We did evacuate him alive after about two weeks of fairly intense stuff.
But I really would be surprised if in the long term he lived through the whole thing.
But at any rate, I went out to the bathroom to hold John.
And I mean, they're sitting down.
with my fatigue pants around my ankles, and somebody comes in, and while I'm doing that, ask me if I've heard about the latest about Sergeant Pennington.
I just, that was it.
I finished what I was doing, strapped on my pants, shoved my wallet in my fatigue pants pocket, and I marched down the road.
I'm leaving.
I'm not coming back here.
That's all there is to it.
And I went stroking off down the brigade road, and it was a big circle, cantonment road with units on either side of it, and on the outside of the outside units, the
log units were on the inside of it and the combat units were on the outside.

And I went down to the brigade officer's open mess which was the boom room which was built out of ammo boxes and it was early yet in the afternoon and there wasn't anybody in there but the bartender and the club officer who was a cripple who refused to be evac'd and so they had found him a light duty job and I demanded a roll of nickels and a drink and
I was provided the same, and I sat down to play the slot machine.
And I don't know how much time passed, but at some point in time, this young lieutenant materialized at my elbow and said, hi, are you a nurse?
And I wanted to say, a really penetrating question, what else will I be in this outfit?
But instead, I looked into those big, very beautiful blue eyes and said, yes, why?
And it was my sweet Lee, who, poor fella, had been, he'll tell his own story about how come he was where he was, but
He wasn't out in the shooting having a good time like everybody else.
And he was very bored.
And then the next day, we went to Saigon shopping.
And after that, we were dating on an almost daily basis.
And after about two months of that, he managed to get himself shot.
But he backed into the third surge and caused quite a bit of turmoil and amused all the medics, who thought that was just really cute to have the young lovers be patient and nurse.
Then, and he asked me to marry him that time, and we piddled around another two months getting our paperwork approved.
It's that thick, the stack of paperwork we had to have done.
And we got married on the first of January after he had gotten wounded the second time.
And I'd been down to see the chaplain about arrangements for the wedding because we decided...

to people let me off this thing out ran the bicycle back but uh anyway that was the day that four of my medics came to me and offered to be litter bearers at my wedding but uh we got married and we went to Hong Kong for a week on R&R for our honeymoon and we came back and and uh
An engineer company, as a wedding present, built us a 12 foot by 24 foot little house in the back of the hospital.
And Lee threw his duffel bag in the corner, put his steel pot on his head, and went off to the ward again.
And I went back to the ward, and other than the fact that I wasn't living in the nurse's shack, my little house was 12 feet behind the nurse's shack.
Everything just went on like before.
My head nurse at the time was a male nurse major named Kaminsky, a major cam.

called me in he said jerry i would like to lay a proposition in front of you make sure i'm a married woman now he said that's the point he said i assume that you would like to be off whenever lee's in from the field i said yeah i like that he said i also assume that now that you're married and won't be partying like you have been he said i assume that you really don't care about whether you're off or not while he's out in the field i said well to some degree he says about this sport and

I will make sure that you're off duty all the time leaves in from the field however long it may be as long as you work every day he's out done at that point in time their norm had been they would go out on Monday and come back on Friday so I figured this was kind of like having every weekend off they stayed gone for 28 days and I worked 12 hour shifts for 28 straight days before they came back
But I got to give Major Cam credit.
The battalion came in about 8.30 in the morning.
At 8.45, he was in his nurse suit.
He was counting the narcotics for me, and he personally relieved me.
And they stayed in for six days.
And I kind of dropped by, and Major Cam said, Let us know when you're back.
And that was how we ran it for the whole rest of the time I was there.
My dad had gotten orders for Da Nang and had come over in,
I want to say April, May, something like that.
And the Marines were on 13-month tours.
The Army was on 12-month tours.
And so Dad was going to go back in, like, June.
And I had got to thinking about this and had decided that, hey, I didn't want to go back and end up in some place like Walter Reed.
And I really, what with Basic and Walter Reed, I had 18 months before my enlistment was up, so...
I extended for six months, and I did that before Matt Lee.
I was already obligated to the extension.
And it worked out fine, because he didn't come in country until July or something like that.
He was pretty close to my dad's schedule.
So I worked out my six-month extension as a happy young bride, and we left together.
And then we went back.
Now, there's an incredible amount of,
anecdotal kinds of things I can do, but that's an overview.
How did the men treat you, the corpsmen that you worked with, and in general the men on the base?
Well, it's not possible to talk about the men monolithically like that.
It was an individual kind of thing.
I had grown up in the Marine Corps.
Now, where what counted was what was on your shoulders.
And it hit me very fast in the Army that this was not necessarily how it was.
And for a woman officer in the Army, it was even worse.
And it chafed me that I had to prove I was who I appeared to be before I could get the kinds of behaviors I wanted to have.
But my dad had given me some awfully good advice.
He suggested that I avoid giving direct orders in any way that I could.
and never spare the common courtesies.
He says, honey, if you please and thank you all the time, people know you have the right to order them to do things.
If you please and thank you, everybody feels nice, and then when you turn around and snap an order, watch the dust.
And indeed, I only gave an order once in that assignment, and it was a watch the dust operation, and it was a guy who needed to be trached.
He had a neck wound, it had swollen up, he was in rigorous breathing, and
It was the middle of the night and one of the corpsmen noticed funky noises and went down there and looked at this guy doing this number and I turned around and just snarled, get this, get that.
Then I ran over and personally collared the doctor out of bed and dragged him over in his skivvies.
And we tracked that kid in about 90 seconds from when we recognized it.
And it was funny, because when it was all over, one of the medics said, gee, Lieutenant, I never heard you say something like that before.
I thought, Dad was right.
And there were a lot of gals with civilian backgrounds who really were under the impression that they weren't supposed to say please and thank you, that somehow that was unofficially.
And yeah, I mean, what did they know except what they'd seen in movies?
And I found that if you were good at what you did and you walked in and with minimum of fuss did it, that it was little to nothing.
Now, some of the younger medics were really susceptible to the fact that we were American girls over there where there wasn't much of that.
And they would get these outrageous crushes and sort of droop around worshiping us from afar.
We all collected our share of that kind of attention, but I think that was inevitable.
Some of the older guys moved into young uncle and big brother roles just for the closeness, I really do think.
It was something that they could conscious-wise feel okay about, but they could be around a feminine presence.
I'd make phone calls on the switch, those dumb field telephones you have to crank,
and get the switch operator, and he'd say, are you an American girl?
I'd say, no, I'm a lieutenant in the nurse corps.
I'm at the Third Surge Hospital.
And he'd say, just keep talking.
Just keep talking.
I want to call the name switch.
I'll put you through.
Just keep talking to me while I'm doing it.
One thing was for sure.
We never had any trouble hitchhiking.
And I never felt at risk, because I was always in groups.
And I was always treated with

utter courtesy I think that it you know when a truckload of guys stopped and picked you up when you wanted to hitchhike over to the PX at the air base well no one was going to get away with being discourteous to you without you know five or six others pounds there wasn't enough of you to go around that's for sure so nobody was going to get away with it uh I had a drunk bank a pass at me once on the pass bus and and I cold cocked him and

got threatened with being charged with striking an enlisted man which i thought was a little unfair but the person who was threatening me with that did not follow through how did you feel about the vietnamese and um our side their side well let me finish the man issue okay the thing that wrangled with me is i felt like the male nurses got all the fun

The month before I arrived, a couple of the more fun-loving nurses from the hospital in Saigon had been off with some boyfriends, fellows with wives and children, back home and feel great pay and a helicopter to fly.
And they had been out joyriding in a helicopter, and the chopper had crashed.
They had taken it through some high-tension wires, and it was probably pilot error.
At any rate, the command's response to this was to forbid all female personnel from flying in rotor-driven aircraft.
except on orders.

Well, I just took this as a tremendous... Because every time they wanted someone to escort a... You know, we'd have somebody we had intubated who had to be hand-bagged down to the neurosurgeon in Saigon or something, which to me was just, you know, combat excitement.
Oh, boy, medics at their best.
I wanted to do this.
And they always let the male nurses go because then they didn't have to cut orders.
Whereas if they'd have sent one of us, they'd have had to sit down with a typewriter and cut orders.

Now, I took this as a challenge, and I managed to explore all the possibilities of fixed-wing aircraft during my stay to the extent that I flew out to the field to see my husband in an L-19, which was not exactly what they had in mind by making that rule about rotor-driven aircraft.
But you know what an L-19 is?
Spot a plane.
Yeah.
It was fun.
It didn't take much charm to get my permission to do that, but they had to call the CO of the 9th Attack Air Force to get permission.
Good thing they didn't ask me whether I had permission, because I didn't.
But I told them where I was going, they just didn't know what it was.
You know, I just told them the name.
They didn't recognize it and didn't want to show their ignorance by asking me.
It was a new chief nurse who'd only been in the country two weeks.
So, you know, I signed out on the board and left.
It was great.
But I finally cracked the gender barrier in pre-op.
After I'd been there about nine months, the major asked me if I wanted to transfer to pre-op.
And I said, I've wanted to transfer to pre-op since I got here.
That's where it's at.
That's what I want to do.
And she said, well, you know, you'll be the only girl.
I said, it's OK. And so I was the only girl nurse in pre-op for about six months.
And it was funny.
The medics had their poker game going in the back room.
When you're the only nurse on, well, they're, you know.
I mean, the male nurses played poker with them, but they never even asked me.

I had this real complex Revlon nail care kit that I had treated myself to, and so when we'd get everything all stocked up and cleaned up and ready for whatever might come, give a couple of DPT shots and be ready to settle in for the rest of the day, I would get this Revlon kit out, and I would commence to give myself a long and painstaking manicure.
Well, it never failed that on the second layer of paint tacky, in would come.
And we'd be in the mud and the web gear and the, you know, all that.
And you'd have to strip it all off and start all over again.
About the third time I did that, the sergeant who was the lead medic on the shift said, Lieutenant, I'd really appreciate it if you wouldn't do that when you're on duty.
I said, well, geez, you know, you're always on duty here.
Wouldn't you expect me to do it?
He said, well, look, the guys are kind of superstitious about it.
They have noticed that every time you're almost done, that your manicure gets ruined by incoming casualties.
And, you know, we'd really appreciate it if you'd do it on night shift.
So, but other than that, I have to admit, they

again if you could do the job and and then then acceptance was not a big problem the news media drove me nuts though oh they'd love to come out and interview us and they always wanted to ask you questions like do you feel that you represent the wives mothers and sweethearts of america because a man fighting in the war i'd say no i really don't see i'm a lieutenant in the army
And I'm a nurse, and I've got my own job here, and I do it, and they're my buddies, and they do their jobs, and I expect them to shoot people, and I expect to take care of them when they get shot.
And that's how it is.
I'm not representing anybody's anything.
I'm just me.
Never did what they taped or shot of me end up on the air.
I was not giving them the answers they came to get.
What's next, the Vietnamese?
How did you feel about the Vietnamese?
Well, I came from a family environment where bigotry wasn't supported.
The Marine Corps integrated its schools when I was a youngster, even though the schools off post weren't.
And I grew up with blacks and Koreans and Germans and all the foreign wives.
A lot of my friends had foreign mothers who were naturalized Americans by that time.

and my mother and father just had never any patience with anybody putting anybody down it's funny in retrospect I realize that the family does have one very bad failing is their intellectual snobs didn't have much much patience with dumb people but as long as you could hold your own right wise it didn't matter what color or shade or religion you were so with that as my background I had uh and I always liked languages and I've been interested in other countries cultures not going near the foreign service school thing
So I had already read all the little books they had out about what's going on in Vietnam.
And I had made a stab at learning the language, which was difficult.
The language is so regional that you go 50 kilometers and they can't understand you.
The accents are so heavy.
Even words are different.
And a lot of people didn't really realize that.
And it's like some of those places in Africa where
one country with 80 dialects.
There's over 200 dialects in India, although it's a fairly large country, but still 200 languages.
So I kind of peeled off.
Now, I spoke French at that point in time.
I'd had four years in high school.
And most of the Vietnamese who were over 35 who were educated spoke French.
So I was able to deal with folk in the market and that kind of thing in French instead of in English.
But I didn't ever know any Vietnamese people.
I mean, even the ones that were employed in our compound.
I mean, the truck came up, they got off, they went to their jobs, and they worked.
And it was, good morning, how are you?
Did I say that right?
Teach me the word for.
But I didn't even know whether some of these women were married or not or whether they had children or not.
To be quite honest, I wasn't interested.
